metadata.case_name: Partnership Firm (Petitioners) v. State of Maharashtra (Respondents)

facts.text: Petitioner is a partnership firm carrying on business of importers and dealers in wines, provisions, drugs and medicines in Bombay.

Mrs. Dorethea Kumpig Leo was tenant of shop No. 1 ground floor, Flat No. G-8/9 first floor, godown No. H/5 in Sitaram Building, C-Block, Dadabhoy Naoroji Road, Fort, Bombay, carrying on boot and shoe making business as Messrs. Lee Co.

By assignment deed dated August 18, 1964, Mrs. Dorethea Kumpig Leo assigned her entire business as going concern, name, goodwill, assets, stock-in-trade, furniture, fixtures and tenancy rights in the premises to petitioners for Rs. 15,001 (Rs. 1,000 for furniture etc., balance incidental to business sale).
After assignment, petitioners carried on their business of importing foreign liquor, wines, provisions, drugs and medicines in the premises.
On or about April 7, 1966, Inspector of Second Respondent visited shop, took statement from partner, given copy of assignment deed, rent bills and documents evidencing occupancy.
On August 8, 1966, Second Respondent issued notice to petitioners to show cause why premises (Shop No. 1, Ground Floor, Sitaram Building) should not be requisitioned.
Petitioners' legal advisers replied on August 12, 1966, requesting postponement due to partner's absence (father's illness), details of inquiry, noting no vacancy.
Second Respondent on August 25, 1966, agreed to postponement and fixed new date.
On August 30, 1966, absent partner replied from Chandigarh requesting further adjournment due to father's illness.
On September 1, 1966, petitioners' lawyers reiterated rights under assignment, requested withdrawal of notice as no vacancy.
On September 19, 1966, Second Respondent informed that premises is case of suppressed vacancy liable to requisition under s.6(4)(a) of Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948.

On September 24, 1966, Second Respondent passed requisition order declaring premises vacant after December 4, 1947, requisitioned for public purpose (Maharashtra State Government Office, found vacant August 1964) under s.6(4)(a).
Petitioners' counsel on September 27, 1966, requested withdrawal detailing circumstances.
Second Respondent on October 3, 1966, refused to revise, directed handover of possession.
Petitioners filed writ petition under Art.32 challenging proceedings, esp. orders Sep 19 and 24, 1966.
Assignment similar to petitioners' protected by Notification dated Sep 24, 1948 under proviso to s.15(1) Rent Act, cl.(2).

Respondents contend assignment is transfer of tenancy rights only, not business (boot/shoe to wines/drugs), not protected by cl.(2); suppressed vacancy, no intimation; needed for Directorate of Ayurveda.

legal_issues.text: Whether there is vacancy under s.6(4)(a) and Explanation (a) to s.6 of Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948, given assignment permitted under cl.(2) of Notification dated Sep 24, 1948 under proviso to s.15(1) of Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947, such that jurisdiction to requisition arises; whether Rent Act and Requisition Act in pari materia.
Whether Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 violates Arts. 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g), not saved by Art.19(5) or 19(6).

petitioner_arguments.text: Assignment dated Aug 18, 1964 valid under cl.(2) Notification under s.15(1) proviso Rent Act as incidental to sale of business as going concern with stock/goodwill/entire interest; no vacancy in fact or law; Explanation (a) s.6 Requisition Act refers only to prohibited transfers; Rent Act and Requisition Act in pari materia due to same scarcity purpose.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Rents Act s.15(1) proviso, Notification cl.(2); Requisition Act s.6 Explanation (a)

petitioner_arguments.text: Requisition Act unconstitutional violating Art.19(1)(f)(g): procedural (jurisdictional fact by executive, conclusive, no hearing/reasons/review); substantive (fiction of vacancy on permitted assignment).

respondent_arguments.text: Assignment is colourable device for tenancy transfer only (business changed from shoes to wines/drugs), not protected by cl.(2) Notification; vacancy on original tenant ceasing business, no intimation; Rent Act provisions not read into Requisition Act, distinct fields.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rent Act s.15(1); Requisition Act s.6(4)(a)

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of Art.19(1)(f)(g): requisition for public purpose; does not affect trade/business; if property, governed by Art.31(2); saved by Art.19(5)(6).

court_reasoning.text: Rent Act (landlord-tenant relations, rent control, eviction) and Requisition Act (requisition of land for public purpose) not in pari materia, different subjects; s.15 Rent Act not read into s.6 Requisition Act; permitted assignment still creates deemed vacancy under Explanation (a) s.6.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two Acts deal with totally different matters; no harmony required beyond express terms.

court_reasoning.text: Assignment is colourable device for tenancy transfer prohibited by s.15(1) Rent Act, not saved by cl.(2) Notification (business nature changed, admissions); petitioners acquire no tenancy/business rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transaction does not satisfy cl.(2) requirements.

court_reasoning.text: Requisition Act deals with property, not trade/business; no need to consider Art.19(1)(g); no fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f)(g) infringed as no valid rights acquired.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioners cannot complain of infringement without valid rights.

holdings.text: Rent Act and Requisition Act not in pari materia; permitted assignment under Rent Act still deemed vacancy under Requisition Act s.6 Explanation (a).
Assignment colourable, invalid; no rights acquired by petitioners; no violation of Art.19(1)(f)(g).

precedents_cited.case_name: Sitabati Devi v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Requisition Act governed by Art.31(2), not testable under Art.19(1)(f)

precedents_cited.case_name: Kadar Nath Singh v. State of Bihar

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 (Bom. Act LVII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Permits certain assignments incidental to business sale; protects transferee as tenant; assignment here not protected as colourable

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Requisition Act, 1948 (Bom. Act XXXIII of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorises requisition of vacant premises; deems vacancy on tenant's assignment/transfer notwithstanding permitted under Rent Act

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation as no valid rights; requisition for public purpose

outcome.summary: Writ petition challenging requisition orders dismissed; assignment held colourable device not protected under Rent Act Notification; no vacancy issue or fundamental rights violation; respondents entitled to requisition.

key_quotes.text: "the assignment, claimed by the petitioners, must be regarded only as a colourable device, for really obtaining a transfer of tenancy rights, which is otherwise prohibited by s.15(1) of the Rent Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding rejecting petitioners' claim to valid assignment

key_quotes.text: "Section 15 of the Rent Act, cannot be read into any part of the Requisition Act, much less with S.6 of the latter Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects in pari materia argument, key to jurisdiction

key_quotes.text: "There is absolutely no similarity between the two enactments and we cannot hold that the Requisition Act relates to the same person or thing, or to the same class of persons or things, as the Rent Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes scopes of Rent Act and Requisition Act
